dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, a lot of people think Trump Tower was always this untouchable symbol of wealth, but it actually started as a struggling construction site.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, a lot of people think Trump Tower was always this untouchable symbol of wealth, but it actually started as a struggling construction site.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. And it's had so many different lives—like, it was the set of Celebrity Apprentice, and then the spot where he announced his 2016 run from that balcony.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. And it's had so many different lives-like, it was the set of Celebrity Apprentice, and then the spot where he announced his twenty sixteen run from that balcony.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump Tower has long played a starring role in Donald Trumps lifefirst as a brand-burnishing real estate project, then as the site of The Apprentice, more recently as a set for the 2016 presidential campaign. It was here, from the downstairs atrium, that Trump announced he was making a bid for the White House.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and later, when he was president-elect, that penthouse hosted big names like Boris Johnson.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and later, when he was president-elect, that penthouse hosted big names like Boris Johnson.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The penthouse atop the tower hosted power brokers like Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan once Trump became president-elect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But what's wild is how the campaign finances played out there. Like, he didn't sell Trump Tower—he kept ownership through Trump Hotels LLC.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what's wild is how the campaign finances played out there. Like, he didn't sell Trump Tower-he kept ownership through Trump Hotels L L C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He retained ownership of the property, through his 100% interest in an entity named Trump Tower Commercial LLC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and according to state filings, his reelection campaign paid zero dollars in rent to that entity, even though he donated 1.6 million to his own campaign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and according to state filings, his reelection campaign paid zero dollars in rent to that entity, even though he donated one point six million to his own campaign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His campaign kept its ties too, continuing to rent space from Trump Tower Commercial LLC. And thus Trump, who has not yet donated anything to his own reelection campaign, managed to collect $1.6 million of supporter money through the property, according to a review of federal filings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, zero? But they did pay 38 grand in rent on August 21st to another part of the business, which experts are saying might be illegal if it's not fair market value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, zero? But they did pay thirty eight grand in rent on August twenty first to another part of the business, which experts are saying might be illegal if it's not fair market value.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes a $38,000 rent payment on August 21, a transaction detailed in the latest filings the Trump campaign submitted to the Federal Election Commission. All of the payments appear to be legal, assuming the Trump team is paying fair-market rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's Trump Resorts LLC, which got like 123 thousand dollars—that one's partly owned by Donald Trump Jr.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's Trump Resorts L L C, which got like one hundred twenty three thousand dollars-that one's partly owned by Donald Trump Jr.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $123,000 has flowed to a second entity, named Trump Restaurants LLC, which the president also owns outright.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, for that showroom space upstairs where they were selling merch, right next to Trump Grill. They pay 30k a month for that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, for that showroom space upstairs where they were selling merch, right next to Trump Grill. They pay 30k a month for that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That company appears to be connected to a space in the lower level of Trump Tower, where the campaign has been selling memorabilia from a small kiosk, wedged between Trump Grill and a souvenir shop. The campaign pays about $3,000 a month for that location, a figure that two real estate experts said seemed appropriate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which some real estate folks called a steal, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which some real estate folks called a steal, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A third, looking at the space from inside the building, concluded it was too much. Thats robbery, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the really big money went to his D.C. hotel—the campaign spent over 3.5 million there in August alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the really big money went to his D.C. hotel-the campaign spent over three point five million there in August alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In August, the Trump campaign spent at least $3,500 at the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., just down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And in total, his hotels have collected 231 million from the reelection effort. It's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And in total, his hotels have collected two hundred thirty one million from the reelection effort. It's just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps hotels have now collected $231,000 from his reelection campaign, according to an analysis of documents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, he's only put in 1.6 million of his own money this cycle? Compared to 66 million in 2016?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, he's only put in one point six million of his own money this cycle? Compared to sixty six million in twenty sixteen?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And thus Trump, who has not yet donated anything to his own reelection campaign, managed to collect $1.6 million of supporter money through the property, according to a review of federal filings. He spent $66 million on his 2016 run.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and with rumors he might only contribute 100 bucks next? It's hard to wrap your head around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and with rumors he might only contribute one hundred bucks next? It's hard to wrap your head around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In early September, rumors surfaced that the president was considering investing as much as $100 million of his own money into his reelection campaign.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, a lot of people think Trump Tower was always this untouchable symbol of wealth, but it actually started as a struggling construction site.
HostB: Oh, for sure. And it’s had so many different lives—like, it was the set of Celebrity Apprentice, and then the spot where he announced his 2016 run from that balcony.
HostA: Right, and later, when he was president-elect, that penthouse hosted big names like Boris Johnson.
HostB: But what’s wild is how the campaign finances played out there. Like, he didn’t sell Trump Tower—he kept ownership through Trump Hotels LLC.
HostA: Yeah, and according to state filings, his reelection campaign paid zero dollars in rent to that entity, even though he donated 1.6 million to his own campaign.
HostB: Wait, zero? But they did pay 38 grand in rent on August 21st to another part of the business, which experts are saying might be illegal if it’s not fair market value.
HostA: Exactly. And then there’s Trump Resorts LLC, which got like 123 thousand dollars—that one’s partly owned by Donald Trump Jr.
HostB: Oh yeah, for that showroom space upstairs where they were selling merch, right next to Trump Grill. They pay 30k a month for that.
HostA: Which some real estate folks called a steal, honestly.
HostB: But the really big money went to his D.C. hotel—the campaign spent over 3.5 million there in August alone.
HostA: And in total, his hotels have collected 231 million from the reelection effort. It’s just staggering.
HostB: Meanwhile, he’s only put in 1.6 million of his own money this cycle? Compared to 66 million in 2016?
HostA: Yeah, and with rumors he might only contribute 100 bucks next? It’s hard to wrap your head around.
